content.html:
When I decided to retool my website at the end of November last year, I wanted to incorporate as much connectedness and as possible to be able to syndicate my discussions and break out of social media silos. By incorporating Webmentions, some of this is achieved.

What are Webmentions?

Webmentions are a form of communication between websites. They allow a website to notify another website when it links to it. In other words, if website A links to website B, website B can receive a notification (a webmention) of the link.

Webmentions are based on a standard that was created as part of the IndieWeb movement, which aims to give people more control over their online identity and data. By using webmentions, websites can build relationships and engage in conversations with each other, just as people do on social media.

In summary, webmentions provide a simple way for websites to interact with each other and exchange information. They allow for decentralized communication and can be used to create a more connected and engaging web.

Here are some examples of how webmentions are used:

  1. Blog comments: Webmentions can be used to allow readers to comment on blog posts without having to use a third-party service. When a reader leaves a comment, their website sends a webmention to the blog post, which then displays the comment.
  2. Social media interactions: Webmentions can be used to bring social media interactions onto a website. For example, if someone tweets about a blog post, the blog can receive a webmention of the tweet and display it on the post‚Äôs page.
  3. Inter-website notifications: Webmentions can be used to notify a website when another website links to it. This allows the linked website to keep track of who is linking to it and to engage in conversations with the linking websites.
  4. Cross-posting: Webmentions can be used to allow a website to cross-post content to multiple sites, such as a blog and a microblog. When a post is made on one site, it sends a webmention to the other site, which then displays the post.

These are just a few examples of how webmentions can be used. They offer a flexible and decentralized way for websites to interact with each other and provide new opportunities for building relationships and engaging with audiences.

And you‚Äôre actually interacting with webmentions right now if you comment on this post. Whether you‚Äôre seeing this on Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, ActivityPub/Mastodon, Micro.blog, all the comments roll back to the original post on the site. Go ahead and comment and after a few minutes check starrwulfe.xyz and see for yourself!

Here are some websites that use webmentions:

  1. IndieWeb.org: This website is dedicated to promoting the IndieWeb movement and serves as a hub for information and resources about webmentions. You can find out more about how all this is done there.
  2. Micro.blog: A microblogging platform that supports webmentions and allows users to easily connect with each other and engage in conversations.
  3. A Mastodon instance: Mastodon is an open-source, decentralized social media platform that uses webmentions to allow users to interact with each other across different instances of the platform.
  4. Brid.gy: A service that bridges the gap between social media and the IndieWeb by allowing users to send webmentions from their social media accounts to their own websites. This is how I‚Äôm able to crosspost and syndicate to other platforms.
  5. Known: A social media platform that is built on the IndieWeb and uses webmentions to allow users to interact with each other and create a more connected web.

These are just a few examples; the technology is still relatively new, but if more websites adopt it, the web is becoming a more connected and engaging place.

summary.html:
Looks like Bridgy can now handle auto-posting from your site to Mastodon (currently using IFTTT, which is convoluted and pretty slow). There‚Äôs also a make your website your Fediverse account, but I don‚Äôt even understand that at the mo, power user stuff.
https://fed.brid.gy/

content.html:
@leonp in my case I effectively get two ActivityPub accounts when counting micro.blog as well‚Ä¶and you can still have the ‚Äútraditional‚Äù post to third party Mastodon site, meaning 3 ways to blog into the Fediverse.

My main reasoning for _site as account_ is
‚Äì being able to centralize all conversation around content from the site.
‚Äì no limits to how long my post will be; if I post as a note, I can go as long as I like.
‚Äì no worries about site load, caching, etc since it‚Äôs effectively a one user instance and ‚Äúheavy‚Äù media is on CDN.
‚Äì it‚Äôs cool to have my site be the ‚Äú@‚Äú name when giving out my Mastodon address. üòù

The drawbacks:
‚Äì no DMs. Maybe @snarfed is working on a way to handle that, but my method is to use my micro.blog handle for that since @manton came up with a good solution for it (you did know micro.blog handles are also AP enabled, right?)
‚Äì federation is ‚Äúwobbly‚Äù; some instances won‚Äôt see your posts until one of their users threads caches it in; I wind up boosting my own posts from other instances to get around it. It‚Äôs not a problem as much as it used to be since there‚Äôs a lot of us using BridgyFed now.

¬†

My main reasoning for _site as account_ is
‚Äì being able to centralize all conversation around content from the site.
‚Äì no limits to how long my post will be; if I post as a note, I can go as long as I like.
‚Äì no worries about site load, caching, etc since it‚Äôs effectively a one user instance and ‚Äúheavy‚Äù media is on CDN.
‚Äì it‚Äôs cool to have my site be the ‚Äú@‚Äú name when giving out my Mastodon address. üòù
The drawbacks:
‚Äì no DMs. Maybe @snarfed is working on a way to handle that, but my method is to use my micro.blog handle for that since @manton came up with a good solution for it (you did know micro.blog handles are also AP enabled, right?)
‚Äì federation is ‚Äúwobbly‚Äù; some instances won‚Äôt see your posts until one of their users threads caches it in; I wind up boosting my own posts from other instances to get around it. It‚Äôs not a problem as much as it used to be since there‚Äôs a lot of us using BridgyFed now.
¬†

content.html:
Hopefully I can pop my head in for an hour to ask a few questions and chat.

Would like to ask about legibility and fonts along with ‚Äúlight‚Äù and ‚Äúdark‚Äù modes and how everyone deals with them; I never really discussed this about personal websites before, so I‚Äôm interested in people‚Äôs choices and experiences when selecting their own site‚Äôs UX/UI.

If I can‚Äôt make it, then next time or in the chat!
